awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Recommender and Decision-Making Systems Seeking Compatible Sets from Multiple Collections under Varying Constraints
awd_abstract_narration:
Recommender systems that assist in decision-making are increasingly used in a number of information settings.  Most research in this area focuses on algorithms that predict how much a user will prefer a given item based on their own and others' past preferences.  Such research tends to treat the question as a machine learning, statistical, or optimization problem; however, this abstracts away important aspects of making recommender systems useful to people, including attending to the decision-making processes and contexts being supported.  This project will develop recommender systems that explicitly attend to these concerns using a smart home as the driving domain.  The methods developed for reasoning in this context can inform similar decision problems in other domains, such as managing supplies and logistics and accessing information. 
        
This project will develop solutions to a number of important but under-addressed challenges for recommender systems, including (1) recommending groups of related items that work well together, rather than individual items; (2) recommending and re-recommending items primarily from an existing set of items rather than focusing on single-use consumption of new items; and (3) considering important factors about both the physical and social environment that affect decision making.  The project will explore these issues in the context of ensemble selection decisions in a smart home.  The system will be grounded in case-based reasoning; this will mitigate the cold start problem that plagues ratings-based collaborative filtering algorithms and fits well with the planned attribute-based representations of items, preferences, and context.  To do this, the team will use 3D scanners and rendering software to create personalized models of items, and both experts and crowdworkers will then assess the model outputs, accounting for social and physical contexts.  This will generate a case library that, along with rulesets for combining items, can be used to generate recommendations for both sets of items and individual items that fit well with already-chosen ones.  The system will be based on an existing prototype, adapted to run on a tablet to support remote data collection.  The deployment includes a setup process where the team will attach RFID tags to items and photograph them for later analysis and addition of attributes; a three-month period in which users' choices and context will be logged but no recommendations are made, and a six-month period where recommendations are offered.  The system will be evaluated in terms of the usefulness of the recommendations, their ability to suggest novel and liked combinations, and their effect on the use and recombination of users? existing items. Through deploying prototype systems in homes, the work will also give insight into designing smart home applications such as activity and medication monitoring that involve object tracking.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the challenge of matching sets of complemetary items from a collection of options, with a focus on human-centered aspects of decision-making like accouting for aesthetic preferences in groupings. Our team found aesthetic factors in creating assemblies of items to be a key influence in the generation of waste (e.g. for clothing products, matching problems lead to unused or underused products). We focused on smart-home applications like wardrobe management, where decision heurstics are often created and disseminated through expert advice.

In our approach, we considered a theory-driven method based on expertise to circumvent the cold-start problem that persists in many domains. We assessed and formalized the theory used by experts in assembling combinations of items, and identified a taxonomoy of the attributes used by experts in describing succesful cases. These were used to establish rules and guidelines. For some attributes, we translated values from imprecise natural-language descriptors to machine-readable standardized formats. In order to assess expert theory (e.g. in relating body attributes to garment attributes) we developed a method for rapid generation of large numbers of 3D visual stimuli with specific aesthetic attributes. Finally, we deployed a large-scale assessment of the ability of expert theory to predict aesthetic judgements of lay evaluators. Through that assessment, we found that some aspects of the expert theoretical approach were strongly predictive of lay judgements while others were not, suggesting a heirarchy of attribute/value relationships. Restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic precluded a planned field deployment, but allowed a more extensive assessment through 3D simulations. 

The research supported by this award integrated knowledge and expertise from individuals trained in computer science, clothing design, data science, human factors engineering, and product design. It represents an inherently interdisciplinary approach to the complex challenge of formal modeling of human-centered decision factors like aesthetics, important in the development of more effective decision-support and recommendation tools. Results of this research have implications for the understanding and augmentation of consumer behavior and consumer decision-making as well as the practice and teaching of product design. For technology development, our results have established a taxonomy of attributes used in defining aesthetic rules or attribute/value relationships, as well as a method and dataset that can be used to test the influence of different attributes in order to establish a priority for automating feature extraction. Beyond the smart home domains we considered, the approach to formalizing expertise to inform reasoning can be applied to other similar domains, especially to inform feature engineering strategies. Importantly, the project also served to further the education and training of a diverse set of individuals. 100% of the project team are members of groups underrepresented in science and engineering disciplines.
